The men heard from the highest quarters a confirmation of what they wanted to believe.
The exhausted, wavering men felt comforted.
The exhausted, wavering men felt inspirited.
Prince Andrew’s regiment was among the reserves.
Prince Andrew’s regiment was stationed inactive behind Semënovsk until after one o’clock.
Prince Andrew’s regiment was under heavy artillery fire.
Toward two o’clock the regiment had already lost more than two hundred men.
Toward two o’clock the regiment was moved forward into a trampled oatfield in the gap between Semënovsk and the Knoll Battery.
Thousands of men perished that day in the oatfield.
An intense, concentrated fire from several hundred enemy guns was directed at the oatfield between one and two o’clock.
The regiment lost another third of its men without moving or firing a single shot.
From the front and especially from the right, in the smoke the guns boomed.
Quick hissing cannon balls flew unceasingly.
Slow whistling shells flew unceasingly.
At times a quarter of an hour passed during which cannon balls and shells flew overhead.
Sometimes several men were torn from the regiment in a minute.
The slain were continually being dragged away.
The wounded were continually being carried off.
With each fresh blow the chance of life for those not yet killed decreased.
The regiment stood in columns of battalion, three hundred paces apart.
The men were always in one and the same mood.
All men were taciturn and morose.
Talk was rarely heard in the ranks.
Talk ceased altogether when the thud of a successful shot and the cry of “stretchers!” was heard.
Most of the time the men sat on the ground by their officers’ order.
One soldier took off his shako and carefully loosened the gathers of its lining and drew them tight again.
Another soldier rubbed some dry clay between his palms and polished his bayonet.
Another soldier fingered the strap and pulled the buckle of his bandolier.
Another soldier smoothed and refolded his leg bands and put his boots on again.
Some soldiers built little houses of the tufts in the plowed ground.
Some soldiers plaited baskets from the straw in the cornfield.
All soldiers seemed fully absorbed in these pursuits.
When men were killed or wounded, no one paid attention to these things.
When rows of stretchers went past, no one paid attention to these things.
When some troops retreated, no one paid attention to these things.
When great masses of the enemy came into view through the smoke, no one paid attention to these things.
When our artillery advanced, words of approval were heard on all sides.
When our cavalry advanced, words of approval were heard on all sides.
When some of our infantry moved forward, words of approval were heard on all sides.
The liveliest attention was attracted by occurrences apart from the battle.
The minds of these morally exhausted men found relief in everyday, commonplace occurrences.
A battery of artillery was passing in front of Prince Andrew’s regiment.
The horse of an ammunition cart put its leg over a trace.
The ranks all along Prince Andrew’s regiment shouted "Hey, look at the trace horse!... Get her leg out! She’ll fall.... Ah, they don’t see it!".
A small brown dog trotted in a preoccupied manner in front of the ranks with tail stiffly erect.
A shell fell close by and the dog yelped.
The dog tucked its tail between its legs and darted aside.
Yells and shrieks of laughter rose from the whole regiment.
Such distractions lasted only a moment.
For eight hours the men had been inactive.
The men had been without food.
The men were in constant fear of death.
Their pale faces grew ever paler.
Their gloomy faces grew ever gloomier.
